1594202842|3.0|This book makes you think about what you want for and from your children, and how you are willing to achieve it. As much as any parent wants to push his or her child to a \\"better place in life,\\" it is important to see how the ends may not outweigh the means. Chua depicts how she, in traditional Chinese fashion, pushed her two daughters to be flawless in almost every aspect of their lives. The relentless Chua nearly destroys her relationship with one daughter because of her refusal to let her daughter be autonomous. Chua tries to make the story look like a learning experience, but to me she seemed almost oblivious to the harm she was inflicting upon her daughter. This is a good book for any parents who have high aspirations for their children because it will give you a chance to reflect on just how far you will be willing to push your children. The book is a quick read and good for reflection (not only about parenting, but also about human nature in general). If you are unsure whether you want to spend your money reading about Chua's psychotic quirks, borrow before you buy.
B001Q7JD5O|5.0|***This review may contain spoilers.***<br /><br />The more I ponder Peter Jackson's re-interpretation of the classic 1933 movie \\"King Kong\\", the more convinced I become that he was at least subconsciously paralleling James Cameron's blockbuster \\"Titanic\\". Like Cameron, Jackson wanted to transcend the basic, naturalistic action and horror aspects of the tale and meticulously explore a relationship that will outlive death and fate. Consider the climax; the airplanes finally succeed in knocking Kong off his Empire State Building pedestal and almost over the edge. He is still clinging by his fingers. He exchanges one last lingering, emotional look with Ann Darrow, then finally lets go. He slowly plummets to the ground. It reminded me of Jack clinging to the driftwood in \\"Titanic\\", exchanging one last sorrowful look with Rose before letting go and plunging to the bottom of the Atlantic.<br /><br />However, the 2005 version of King Kong (hereafter KK2005) is not strictly a love story. There really isn't any romance, even between Ann and Jack. It is the story of a tortuous, danger-fraught, but ultimately enduring friendship between an unemployed actress and a dinosaur-sized ape. It may remind you a little of \\"Gorillas in the Mist\\", the movie about naturalist Dian Fossey's relationship with the endangered simians. The 3-hour movie running time may be annoying to some, and sometimes understandably so, but it is utterly necessary to explore the developing interaction between Ann and Kong, and to reveal that Kong is not a legendary demon, but a natural, sentient beast who is the last of his species. Besides, he is strictly a vegetarian (remember him munching on the bamboo?). Make no mistake, Ann certainly fears Kong at first, but her previous hard-scrabble life and talents give her the determination and moxie to take control of the situation. So much so that Kong is even perplexed by her and eventually leaves her, until the dangers of Skull Island, culminating in an attack by three (!) Tyrannosaurus Rexes reunite the duo and give Ann's champion quite a workout!<br /><br />The jungle battles Kong fights on Ann's behalf are more exciting than the perils Carl Denham, Jack Driscoll, and the Venture's sailors encounter on Skull Island because a relationship is at stake and you care about it. In contrast, as when Carl, Jack, and crew encounter the sauropod stampede, and the monstrous insects, spiders, and other arthropods, while as technically accomplished as the T-rex battles, I think the action actually becomes a little bit wearisome and dull because we are less interested in them. We appreciate the time Kong and Ann find to spend together on the island and despair when Carl and company finally chloroform and capture the rampaging ape for transport, and Ann futilely screams to leave him alone.<br /><br />In a departure from the original 1933 movie, and even in the 1976 movie, Ann is not present when Kong is shackled and on display in a New York theater. Protesting Kong's humiliating captivity, Ann instead returns to her acting company. Kong (comically) winces at the phony actress tied up in front of him in a parody of the Skull Island sacrifice of Ann. But of course nothing can sever their friendship; again, Kong breaks free, causes considerable property damage, and somehow (how, exactly?) reunites with Ann. Despite the rampage, I think you feel sorry for Kong, cast loose and alone in a terrifying and wintry neon civilization with only Ann to which to turn. Together again, they manage to enjoy a Central Park interlude and even a sunrise view from the Empire State Building before the military and the biplanes cruelly shatter the magic.<br /><br />Again, many viewers felt KK2005's length hamstrung the movie. I disagree; it gave the movie breathing room to not only develop a deep friendship, but also a rousing exotic adventure, a conservation-minded treatise, some natural horror, a Depression-era time capsule, and the fleshing-out of an archetype. To get the most out of this movie, give it time to let it carry you away and console you with the fact that in spite of everything, Kong and Ann will always have Skull Island and New York.<br /><br />Now for some random (and fanciful) observations:<br /><br />1. The sauropods that Carl and company encounter and eventually cause to stampede do not look like Brontosaurs (Apatosaurs). They look like Camarasaurs with the boxy, deep heads. It was a shame to see such a magnificent herd hurdle off the cliff. By the way, being in the middle of that stampede, it was a miracle none of Denham's party gets trampled.<br /><br />2. As other posters as noted, the rough, brutal way Kong handles Ann as he crashes and fights his way through the island should have turned her into a shapeless mass of protoplasm.<br /><br />3. Again, we have the $64,000 question: after chloroforming Kong, how did Carl and company float Kong to the ship and transport him thousands of miles to New York? I don't think Kong could even fit on or in the ship. Only the 1976 version of King Kong answers that question by hauling him in a colossal oil tanker.<br /><br />4. The Central Park sequence where he plays on the ice pond with Ann is beguiling but doesn't make much sense. Unless the pond were frozen all the way to the bottom, wouldn't Kong's estimated 20 tons have broken through? Also, as a tropical animal, wouldn't the New York winter have been uncomfortable, in spite of his fur?<br /><br />5. If Jackson really wanted to do a homage of \\"Titanic\\", he should have begun his picture in the present day. For example, he could have had a road crew discover a mysterious, giant skeleton while digging up a street. Archeologists and scientists are baffled, until an aged Ann Darrow arrives and identifies the skeleton as Kong. Then, with tears in her eyes, she begins her sad tale.<br /><br />6. Now that Skull Island is no longer a myth, Carl Denham could have recouped his losses by developing a wildlife park (oh, wait, that's Jurassic Park!).ype. To get the most out of this movie, give it time to let it carry you away and console you with the fact that in spite of everything, Kong and Ann will always have Skull Island and New York.<br /><br />Now for some random (and fanciful) observations:<br /><br />1. The sauropods that Carl and company encounter and eventually cause to stampede do not look like Brontosaurs (Apatosaurs). They look like Camarasaurs with the boxy, deep heads. It was a shame to see such a magnificent herd hurdle off the cliff. By the way, being in the middle of that stampede, it was a miracle none of Denham's party gets trampled.<br /><br />2. Again, we have the $64,000 question: after chloroforming Kong, how did Carl and company float Kong to the ship and transport him thousands of miles to New York? I don't think Kong could even fit on or in the ship. Only the 1976 version of King Kong answers that question by hauling him in a colossal oil tanker.<br /><br />4. The Central Park sequence where he plays on the ice pond with Ann is beguiling but doesn't make much sense. Unless the pond were frozen all the way to the bottom, wouldn't Kong's estimated 20 tons have broken through? 0375842209|4.0|Through the eyes of Death, this book lets us experience what it was like to live in Germany during World War II. Although Death may seem like an unlikely narrator, he is the perfect voice to describe the events that are depicted in this book. It captivates you from beginning to end, and will have you turning the pages well into the night. Rarely does one come across a book that once you finish it, you want to go back to page one and read it all over again. The characters were so real and raw; you were instantly drawn to them. This book tugs at heartstrings and makes you laugh and smile and feel for the characters in the book. It truly is a remarkable read, and even though it might be classified as a young adult book, it deals with circumstances that are so real to us, that it really is fit for any age group. Markus Zusak writes in a distinctive style, with imagery so profound, and in a way that is so different from other books. It doesn't have much mystery, since Death is the narrator; along the way he tells you the ending of the book. But although the ending is not shrouded in mystery, it works for the flow of the book. This book will make you laugh and cry and sit in awe at the power of the words that are written. This book is explosive, much like the events that occur in it, and it will stay with you for a long time.

1402210795|5.0|In my opinion, this book owes more to Oscar Wilde than Jane Austen.  It reminds me of \\"The Importance of Being Earnest\\" and \\"An Ideal Husband\\". Financially embarassed due to his wild lifestyle, in a fit of pique he vows to marry the first woman he meets.  That woman is Hero Wantage, at seventeen seven years Sherry\\"s junior, whom he has known since she was eight.  She is is about to be shipped off to be a governess by the unloving aunt who raised her.  Sherry sees their marriage as a win-win situation; Hero can avoid becoming a governess and see life beyond the countryside where she has been raised,  and Sherry can get hold of his inheiritance while continuing to live his life as he has been.  Hero is agreeable since she has had a crush on Sherry for as long as she can remember. He has to continually has to come to her rescue,  with the aid of Gil and Ferdy, his best friend and cousin respectively.  I love Gil and Ferdy, two men not blessed with an abundance of brain power, but who make up for it with their big hearts.  And Gil turns out to be something of a dark horse, coming up with a solution when things go awry that makes for happy endings all around.  Lord Wrotham and Miss Milford, who in a more conventional romance would be the principles,  are here relagated to supporting characters.  The story is a delightful bit of fluff that will have you smiling from beginning to end.

1592402690|3.0|Previous reviewers here have said it well. The amount of information Emerick provides into the inner workings of these classic records and this monumental band is fascinating and worth the read. But the author himself comes off as petty and egotistical. Sometimes it's simply funny - like when he's describing Paul McCartney in glowing, heavenly terms, over and over. Until it turns obnoxious - like when he uses the term &#34;ham fisted&#34; for the 20th time to describe George Harrison's solos (of which any discerning music fan recognizes as masterpieces of economy and innovation). The implicit story that emerges is that, for some reason, Emerick seemed to think he should have been at the forefront of this band's attention while they were at work creating masterpieces in the studio. And when they didn't pay enough attention to him, or treat him as an equal or peer, he took it personally. The thing that is most offensive, even worse than his belittling of George Harrison, John Lennon and Ringo Star's amazing individual musical abilities, is the way in which he tries to downplay the significance of George Martin. As an outsider with no intimate knowledge of who did what on these recordings, even I can plainly see the ignorance in that perspective and it just makes Emerick seem silly, not to mention vacant.  Emerick did a wonderful, wonderful job recording the band. That fact can't be over-stated (though he does try). Mostly it's just a bummer to see him tarnish his own legacy this way, painting himself as an innovative technician with the soul of a turd.  The Beatles and Martin don't need defending. The record speaks for itself, so to speak. Their recordings done without Emerick, such as Rubber Soul, sound equally gorgeous - they were an amazing band on record with or without him. Conversely, most people will agree the one record they made without George Martin (Let it Be) clearly suffered. Draw your own conclusions.

0307477479|4.0|This is not exactly a book to savor, but the first-, second-, and third-person narrators, skipping forward and backward in time, make this book something of a marvel, something to admire.  I have to say that the first chapter was a turnoff, though.  Sasha is a remorseless kleptomaniac who pilfers pieces of other people's lives, perhaps attempting to assemble one of her own.  She works as an assistant to Bennie, a record producer, whose story we hear next.  From there, we move on to Rhea, who was in Bennie's garage punk band, and then to Lou, Bennie's mentor, who takes some hangers-on and his children on a disastrous African safari.  Then we meet Scotty, another bandmate of Bennie's, who delivers him a dead fish as a gift, and I'm on board.  It's a daisy chain in which the link (not to be confused with the character Linc!)that carries forward to the next chapter is always a surprise, right down to the 75-page Powerpoint presentation, which is itself a daisy chain of arrows, flowcharts, pyramids, equations, and bullet points.  As has-been rocker Bosco says, \\"Time is a goon,\\" and we can't predict who is going to come out ahead and who is going to be sapped by the goon.  I just read Einstein's Dreams by Alan Lightman, which, as you might guess, also focuses on time, and I'd be interested to know if Egan has some interest or experience in physics.  In fact, in Goon Squad, Jules Jones, a former celebrity reporter in jail, footnotes the account of his ill-fated interview with a starlet with comments about particle entanglement, a spooky property of photons that seems to parallel the manner in which the characters go their separate ways and then accordion back together or form a closed loop to one another.  Last but not least, there's the obsession of a child with the pauses in music that make you think the song is over when it's really not.  Perhaps these pauses are a metaphor for the spans of time in these characters' lives in which they seem to have lost their way and then manage to scramble back for at least one more stanza.    Here's my daisy chain.  The title of this book makes me think of the TV show The Mod Squad.  It had a character named Linc, and so does this book.  The TV show also starred Peggy Lipton, who lived for a time with record producer Lou Adler.  This book has a record producer named Lou.  Go figure.

B003HARV3Y|3.0|This movie has the most mixed set of reviews of any that I can recall seeing. At one end of the spectrum are those who think this is a great movie and are impressed by the fact that it's about Greek mythology. At the other end are those who loved the book and can't get over the differences in the film version. Somewhere in between are the rest of us.    Dealing with the five-star reviews first- have you people seriously not seen any movies better than this one? It's an exciting enough adolescent caper, with state-of-the-art special effects (already, of course, outdated). The principal character is likeable, his sidekick is funny and the girl, who remains just a friend, is attractive. The three of them set out on a quest to save the world from evil. Now, let me think, has that idea ever been used before? I'll just repeat the name in case you missed it: Per-cy Jack-son. Does that happen to remind you of Har-ry Pot-ter, by any amazing coincidence? As for Greek mythology- this story tells you nothing about it except the names. The author, instead of calling the three brothers Zeus, Poseidon and Hades, could have called them Larry, Moe and Curly and it wouldn't have made the story one jot less authentic. Indeed, he DOES call Medusa 'Auntie Em'; so much for Greek classicism. Take the movie for what it is, a rather derivative romp with no real substance, and enjoy it- but don't award it five stars.    As for the one-star crowd, why is it impossible for you to accept that a movie is not the same vehicle for a story as a book? If the director had tried to create a movie as faithful to the book as you would like (several people mentioned as one of their complaints that the character Annabeth has dark hair instead of blonde- is there no nit too small to pick?) the film would have been so long that everyone would have gone to sleep long before the intrepid trio got anywhere near the underworld. The test is not whether the movie is faithful to the book, but whether it works as amovie. Try to separate the two in your mind and you'll find you enjoy your evening a whole lot more than if you sit there muttering \\"That wasn't in the book.\\" By the way, I read the book before I saw the movie, so don't accuse me of not knowing how wonderful the book is (it isn't, but that's another story).    In short, those who opted for a star choice somewhere in the middle have got it right. The average review rating is three stars and that's exactly what this movie deserves. It's an enjoyable, light-hearted couple of hours, with a good director and a decent cast. It's not a classic and it's not a dud. Now, if you'll excuse me, I must get to Auntie Em's before they close. I need a few more statues for the garden.
B003ZHQVJO|5.0|May I dare say this is one of the best albums I own...    Kid Rock has gone through a very unique career.  I've never seen a mainstream artist's style of music change so slowly and drastically over time.  From \\"Devil Without a Cause\\" to \\"Born Free\\", you can tell he's inching, CD by CD, towards a sound that resembles some southern rock, some country, and a touch of blues.  With that change in genre style, he's also shown maturity.  You now hear words and phrases of wisdom instead of profanity.  Heart Ache, instead of promiscuity.  For me, listening to this album is a peaceful, relaxing experience.  Music couldn't be any more laid back, yet at the same time remaining upbeat, and giving you an urge to clap your hands along with it.  You can hear Kid Rock's free spirit attitude poor through his lyrics.  In that same regard, you can almost compare him to Lynyrd Skynyrd.  You get no sense of Kid Rock's popularity and wealth throughout the album.  He sings about life and relationships as if hes a normal, southern (even though hes from Michigan), lower class guy trying to live life.    I have been a fan of Kid Rock since \\"Devil Without a Cause\\".  My ears have evolved over the years to not only allow me to remain a fan, but to become an even bigger one.  With that said, I can understand fans or critics that have lost all interest in him.  After all, if someone is strictly a rap/rock fan then I can't blame them for losing interest.  There is no longer even a trace of that old style in this latest album.  Not even an 'F' Bomb.    I'm sure the younger generation is aware of this CD (and either loves or hates it), but for the slightly older folks, who don't know what \\"Devil Without a Cause\\" is, and you enjoy some country twang, or laid back southern rock and roll, I couldn't recommend this album more.

B0017R5UA0|4.0|Turntable used:  AT-LP120-USB with an AT120E stylus.<br /><br />I won't go into the music itself, as there are enough of those types of reviews.  This is my review of just the sound quality of the vinyl.  Bottom line: I have the CD and I have the vinyl, and the vinyl is superior.<br /><br />Reason is simple:  On some of the CD tracks, the loudness levels are such that you can actually hear some \\"fuzziness\\" on the louder parts -- for example, At around the 1 minute range on \\"Ragged Wood\\" on the CD, the loudness is so high that the dynamic range is affected.  However, that \\"fuzziness\\" does not exist on the vinyl - it's clearly noticeable in an A/B test.<br /><br />Bottom line:  If you are looking for a best SQ for this album, imo you should get the vinyl.  There is definitely a difference between the two.<br /><br />I did chop off one star only because I have found spots on my vinyl where there seems to be defects in the sound, from time to time (some short \\"crackling\\") - I'm reasonably sure that it's the record and not my stylus or turntable.  Still, I will gladly take these small defects for the overall sound improvement.<br /><br />7/2011 EDIT:  I've since found a foorbar2000 plugin to check dynamic range, which confirms what my ears were hearing. The CD clocks in at a \\"7\\" (which is not very good), and the vinyl clocks in at \\"11\\" which is a significant improvement.

While I usually cruise through books I love (don't do the laundry, make my kids make their own dinner) I actually found myself slowing my reading down with this book. I found the prose lyrical, and I wanted to savor it slowly. The plot pacing was slow at times, but that did not bother me at all. In fact, it made me slow down with it. One of the many criticisms that I read of this book, was that the relationship between Diana and Matthew was not consummated immediately. While I may have had a personal preference for reading about some hot sex, it actually fit the story being told to not have that happen.     As opposed to most urban fantasy these days, our heroine is not a kick-ass private detective. She cries alot, and doesn't know how to use her innate magic. She's a historian, and frankly acts like I think a historian would act. Her beau, Matthew is a 1500 vampire/warrior/scientist. He does act like a cave-vampire sometimes, but that is who he is. I loved the history, the science, and the vampire/witch lore woven into the story, and cannot wait for the sequel.

B004LWZW24|4.0|The Review:<br /><br />From the makers of Paranormal Activity 1 and 2 comes a new horror movie, Insidous, starring Patrick Wilson and Rose Byrne.  The Paranormal Activity people have not lost their touch and Insidious is an excellent example of how to make a scary movie without having to overly rely on creating a gorefest. Rather, Insidious opts for creating and sustaining tension, playing the audience masterfully.  You'll jump just when Insidious` creators want you to jump and you'll scream just when they want you to scream. Watch it in the right frame of mind and with a good audience and you'll be creeped out.<br /><br />As with Paranormal Activity, Insiduous takes the haunted house genre and combines it with the demon possessed child genre, a la Omen and the Exorcist. It throws in a pinch of A Nightmare on Elm Street and the result is something unique and extremely entertaining for devotees of the horror genre. It's clever and offers important new wrinkles for how our protagonists are supposed to deal with their situation.  One can move out of a haunted house, but one cannot easily move away from a haunted family member.<br /><br />Insidous centers around the Lambert Family: Josh, Renai, Dalton and Foster.  At first there's nothing about this family that marks them as abnormal, but as things progress it becomes clear that there is a very dark cloud hanging over them.  As with the folks in Paranormal Activity, the classic signs of a house haunting begin when the Lambert family moves into their new home.  Things move around, strange noises come out of the baby monitor and shadows seem to have a life of their own.  Mom, and the kids seem to notice these things first and Dad is determined to rationalize away these strange happenings.  Things progress to a point that even Josh cannot deny the evidence any longer.  Without giving too much away, there are indeed supernatural forces at play and they have not settled upon the Lambert clan by mere chance.<br /><br />Insidious succeeds because you are on the same journey of discovery as the Lambert family.  You learn alongside them answers to the question, why them? And the further you go, the more insidious their problems appear, hence the film's title.  Another winner from the makers of Paranormal Activity.  If you are easily creeped out, then think twice about this seeing this movie.  While nothing will ever creep me out as much the little girl from The Ring, Insidous left me leaving on an extra light or two around the apartment, and very thankful that I don't live in a creepy old house.<br /><br />FTC Advisory: We purchased our own tickets.the same journey of discovery as the Lambert family. B004LUHQ1G|5.0|Maybe the words \\"raw\\" and \\"heavy\\" aren't the first adjectives that spring to mind when you think of Dave Grohl and the Foo Fighters, and yet, they've managed to pull off an album late into their career that falls into such categories. \\"Wasting Light,\\" the band's first full-length offering in nearly four years, finds the band re-uniting with original guitarist Pat Smear (who you may recall also toured with Nirvana) and joining forces with \\"[[ASIN:B000003TA4 Nevermind]]\\" producer Butch Vig to create a record that brings back the more stripped down and in-your-face vintage Foo Fighters (circa 1995) sound and serves to just about eclipse anything the band has done since the turn of the century. Yep, it's that good.<br /><br />From the opening staccato riff of \\"Burning Bridge,\\" it's clear that this is a different brand of Foo Fighters than radio has learned to love and play the heck out of during the past decade and a half; however that's not to say that Grohl's penchant for irresistible hooks and melodic muscle have been completely abandoned. True, nothing the likes of \\"Everlong\\" rears its head on the eleven blistering tracks that make up the album, but cuts like \\"These Days\\" and \\"I Should Have Known\\" (which happens to sport a guest spot by Grohl's former bandmate in Nirvana, Krist Novoselic on both accordion and bass) provide the moodier, more atmospheric contrasting moments to the album's otherwise reckless and ruthless rocking nature. Then of course you have cuts like \\"White Limo\\" which essentially provides the album's mission statement of creating no-holds barred and no-strings attached pure rock that serves as a throwback to a time long gone. And no one could do it better than these guys.<br /><br />Put simply, \\"Wasting Light\\" is the best Foo Fighters album in a good, long while. Old-school fans will be pleased at the return-to-form while newer fans will be shocked to hear the band punching out tunes that take a complete 180 from the likes of \\"Learn to Fly\\" and \\"Wheels.\\" With this album, the band sounds tighter than ever while Grohl has truly established himself as a rock hero no longer eclipsed by his time spent in that other band. \\"Wasting Light\\" simply rocks like no other and is most certainly not a waste of cash. Heck, fans who scoop up a copy of the initial pressing get an actual piece of the tape the band used to record the album. How's that for motivation to get your butt away from the computer and actually buy an album for once?album, the band sounds tighter than ever while Grohl has truly established himself as a rock hero no longer eclipsed by his time spent in that other band. \\"Wasting Light\\" simply rocks like no other and is most certainly not a waste of cash. Heck, fans who scoop up a copy of the initial pressing get an actual piece of the tape the band used to record the album. How's that for motivation to get your butt away from the computer and actually buy an album for once?

0792844890|5.0|Despite it's having been around long before that time, I first saw this movie on the afternoon of my 21st birthday, courtesy of my sister. Being a fan of such crude films as Monty Python's The Meaning of Life, Holy Grail and Beavis and Butthead Do America, I quickly took to this movie. The story makes little to no sense but it's still funny as all get out.    The story of Spaceballs is simple in its way. The evil, imperious forces of Planet Spaceball, having foolishly squandered their entire planet's air supply in the matter of only a few decades, have set their sites on the shielded planet Druidia, where lie ten-thousand years of fresh, breatheable air. Unfortunately they must first open the combination locked air shield. To do this, the Spaceballs, in an operation spearheaded by the evil Dark Helmet (an obvious spoof on Dath Vader and about as whacky as Vader isn't), attempt to kidnap Druidia's only princess, Princess Vespa, who is engaged though unhappily to Prince Valium, the last prince left in the galaxy. In fact, she's just left her groom-to-be standing, or rather sleeping, at the altar as the Spaceballs begin to close in. In desperation, King ROland of Druidia calls on the services of freelancer Lone Star and his Mog sidekick Barf, the duo being a combination spoof of Luke Skywalker and Han Solo and Chewbacca. The duo arrives just ahead of the Spaceballs and, though they manage to spirit the haughty princess and her Droid of Honor Dot Matrix away, are forced by a lack of fuel to land on the desert planet Vega. Tracked to that locale by Helmet, the fugitives nonetheless make their way quite by accident to the lair of the all-powerful Yogurt, who instructs Lone Star in the use of the Schwartz, the greatest magic in the universe. This comes in quite handy, as during their stay Princess Vespa is lured away by Dark Helmet, another master of the Schwartz, and Lone Star and Barf must take off for Spaceball City to rescue her.    All in all this is one of the funniest movies I've seen in my entire life. And the added commentary by Mel Brooks only adds to the humor. And the fact that it parodies not merely Star Wars but the conventions of most if not all Scifi movies and fairytales and even current pop culture at that time as well is just another treat to add to the mix.

B002SJIO4A|4.0|`District 9' was like that surprise hit of 2009, the film that no one expected to `go the distance', the one that racked up some surprising Oscar nominations (I think everyone expected that Visual Effects nomination, but Best Picture, Screenplay and Editing were pretty unexpected) and continued to astound critics and audiences alike.  I had been sitting on actually seeing this film for a while now, despite really wanting to see it.  I finally got around to seeing this the other night, and I must say that I approach this review with equal parts respect and bewilderment.<br /><br />The film is very good, but it misses greatness in my eyes.<br /><br />`District 9' references a slum that houses aliens that have landed in Johannesburg and have been populating the area for several decades.  Their mother-ship hovers ominously in the horizon, reminding the humans that the aliens are still there.  The humans have segregated the aliens, confining them to a small and disgusting area and have regarded them as nothing but trash, referring to them as `prawns'; a derogatory term used to label them bottom-feeders.  On the outset of the film we are told, in documentary form, that the aliens are about to be evicted and moved to another location.  Head of this particular assignment is Wikus Van De Merwe, a nave and slightly odd young man whose father-in-law obviously favors him (but doesn't truly care for him).  While serving eviction notices and checking for illegal weapons, Wikus stumbles upon a device harvesting fluids that the aliens have been working on for twenty years.  That devise infects Wikus and soon he finds himself morphing into one of the aliens.  His department tries to use him as a test experiment and when he escapes they do what they can to track him down and cover up their own negligence.  Soon he is a fugitive with nowhere to turn but the one place he doesn't want to be a part of, District 9.<br /><br />The film is smarter than your average science fiction film in that it actually roots for a human core, something that can connect it to our world and speak to a deeper message.  In fact, it attains what it is searching for, especially on the surface.  `District 9' is absorbing and provocative, and that is a great asset to have within this genre, for it sets it apart and makes the audience take notice.  The action sequences are outstanding and the visual effects are tremendous (I prefer these authenticated visuals to `Avatar's cartoonesque appearance).  And yet, with such a sharply conceived idea (contrasting alien treatment with the apartheid) the film lacks the layers it needed to make this feel more human.  I'm tired of the whole idea that evil is one-note; that it is without levels of emotion.  In `District 9' it is apparent that humans are selfish and mean and aliens are misunderstood and kindhearted.  Even after being completely stepped on and stabbed in the back by a human, one of the aliens refuses to leave him alone in the sight of danger.<br /><br />`District 9' is far too black and white for its own good.<br /><br />Despite this flaw (ugh, why did it have to be there), this film is really well thought out and expertly crafted.  Director/writer Neill Blomkamp is one to watch for, since he really has a handle on this thing.  He has created a shockingly sincere and beautifully unique science fiction film that shows extreme promise for the young director (he's only six years older than me and look at where he is in his life!!!).for a human core, something that can connect it to our world and speak to a deeper message.  In fact, it attains what it is searching for, especially on the surface.  `District 9' is absorbing and provocative, and that is a great asset to have within this genre, for it sets it apart and makes the audience take notice.  The action sequences are outstanding and the visual effects are tremendous (I prefer these authenticated visuals to `Avatar's cartoonesque appearance).  And yet, with such a sharply conceived idea (contrasting alien treatment with the apartheid) the film lacks the layers it needed to make this feel more human.  I'm tired of the whole idea that evil is one-note; that it is without levels of emotion.  In `District 9' it is apparent that humans are selfish and mean and aliens are misunderstood and kindhearted.  Even after being completely stepped on and stabbed in the back by a human, one of the aliens refuses to leave him alone in the sight of danger.      `District 9' is far too black and white for its own good.    Despite this flaw (ugh, why did it have to be there), this film is really well thought out and expertly crafted.  Director/writer Neill Blomkamp is one to watch for, since he really has a handle on this thing.  He has created a shockingly sincere and beautifully unique science fiction film that shows extreme promise for the young director (he's only six years older than me and look at where he is in his life!!!).
0470876417|4.0|I can only recommend reading the \\"Business Model Generation\\". It lightens up the day with it's straightforward no fuss language and approach.    Read it!
B0041KKYEM|4.0|Last year the world went kind of crazy for `Black Swan', the film that finally brought the world of Darren Aronofsky into the limelight for all to see.  Aronofsky has been creating quality and uniquely intriguing films since the late 90's, and he has brushed Oscar's hand before (garnering acting nominations for `Requiem for a Dream' and `The Wrestler') but it was the bizarrely obsessive `Black Swan' that finally garnered him an acting win (Natalie Portman) as well as Best Picture and Best Director nominations.  It surprises me that this film was `the one' since it is his most immature film to be quite honest.  That isn't to say that it isn't littered with wonderful treats, and Aronofsky's manic yet oddly controlled direction was most deserving of a nomination, but at the end of the day this film is middle-brow Aronofsky at best.<br /><br />I told a friend that this film was like a strange blend of `The Red Shoes' and `Carrie' (two masterpieces) directed by Lars von Trier (genius auteur) with a more polished production thanks to a larger budget.<br /><br />Yes, `Black Swan' is an ugly duckling.<br /><br />The film centers around a young ballerina named Nina who is desperately seeking perfection.  She wants the lead role in her company's revival of `Swan Lake' and she obsesses over the idea of being the Swan Queen, so much so that her whole world starts to take a dark tone.  She is virginal and innocent and childlike in many ways, and so she lacks the otherworldly knowledge to play the dual role part, but she is talented and thus believed in and so she is given the part.  Nina needs to break free from the constraints of her personality, but her upbringing (and her monstrously intrusive mother) makes it hard for her to `let go'.  Then Nina meets Lilly, a young ballerina, new to the company, who possesses everything that Nina lacks; namely sex appeal.  Nina becomes consumed with Lilly, mainly because she is afraid of her.  She begins to suspect that Lilly only wants to take away the lead role from her, and when Lilly is made her alternate she begins to lose her mind with fearful anxiety.<br /><br />`Black Swan' is a very blunt film that doesn't really know the word `restraint', which to be honest is part of the appeal.  The film doesn't hesitate to dive off the crazy train and make a free-fall for deeper waters, especially in the film's final act (which is a visceral work of genius).  The preposterous of the film is highlighted and embraced by Aronofsky's fearless direction, and so you have to appreciate that that is the impression he wanted to make.  Still, there is a feeling of cheapness that erodes some of my affection for the film.<br /><br />I also found that the film's ensemble was very lacking.  There are no layers to these characters.  They are mere caricatures, props for Aronofsky to toy with as he pleases.  I know that a lot of hoopla was made over Natalie Portman and her eventual Oscar win, but I honestly didn't find a lot of depth in her performance.  She was just crazy.  She never really got under the skin of Nina, uncovering who she really was.  Granted, the more I see and contemplate the film I gather that understanding the complexities of Nina wasn't really the point (this film is guilty pleasure personified) but a little depth explored would have fleshed her out and made her more understandable.  Barbara Hershey was also kind of one-note and clich&eacute;d, and not in the way that made her interesting.  Vincent Cassel was horrendous, his line readings were awkward and unbelievable.  In fact, as much as her awards attention baffled me, Mila Kunis was probably the best performance in the film; creating someone we were enthralled with and toying with Nina in a playfully seductive and mysterious manner.<br /><br />And yet still, the film is electrifying and unforgettable.  The cinematography, costume design, makeup, sound (OMG, the way you can hear every swipe of Nina's feet on the floor is to die for), editing and that beautifully haunting reworking of `Swan Lakes' score is just delicious to watch, and Darren Aronofsky knows exactly how to play the audience, drawing us in despite the film's apparent flaws.  This may be Darren's most immature film, but it's quite possibly his best directorial accomplishment.<br /><br />So in the end, I can't hate this film.  I don't understand the unabashed love for it, but I do understand the obsession over it.  It is a film about obsession that captivates its central core by defining obsession.  It oozes with charisma and sucks you in full throttle.core is just delicious to watch, and Darren Aronofsky knows exactly how to play the audience, drawing us in despite the film's apparent flaws.  This may be Darren's most immature film, but it's quite possibly his best directorial accomplishment.    So in the end, I can't hate this film.  I don't understand the unabashed love for it, but I do understand the obsession over it.  It is a film about obsession that captivates its central core by defining obsession.  It oozes with charisma and sucks you in full throttle.

B00005MM01|5.0|I originally bought the single vinyl LP \\"Wear Your Love Like Heaven\\" when it was first released, and it was my favorite album.  When the local store started carrying \\"A Gift...\\" I conned a friend to trade an Animals record for my \\"Wear Your Love...\\" album and bought \\"A Gift...\\".<br /><br />This was one of my all-time favorite albums of the late-60s.  From what I understand, it was the first Rock album Box Set.  The original vinyl box set packaging is beautiful and contains a nice set of prints with drawings and the lyrics to all the songs on the second album.  I still have those prints/lyrics, carefully preserved!<br /><br />Other reviews have mentioned that the CD liner notes are too small.  I agree, however this is true about all CDs, and one area where there has been a true loss over the years.  Album art reached a peak in the 1960s, during those vinyl years when the package was large enough to appreciate the art and read the liner notes.  The packaging on this album in particular suffered, as both the exterior and interior art, as well as liner notes and lyrics are quite wonderful, and can't really be appreciated in the tiny CD format.<br /><br />As I mentioned, the set was originally broken up into two albums, \\"Wear Your Love Like Heaven\\" and \\"For Little Ones\\".  I believe the record company was afraid the double album would not sell as well, and were subsequently proved wrong.<br /><br />In any case, the basic premise is that \\"Wear your Love...\\" was for adults and \\"Little Ones\\" was for children.  But, in fact, some of the songs on \\"Wear  Your Love...\\"  (e.g. \\"Oh Gosh\\", \\"Someone Singing\\") could easily be viewed as children's songs, and some songs on \\"Little Ones\\" (e.g. \\"Enchanted Gypsy\\", \\"Voyage Into the Golden Screen\\", \\"Isle of Islay\\") could have been included on the \\"adult\\" album.<br /><br />I would say the first album is a bit more electric and psychedelic, whereas the second album is more acoustic (i.e. \\"unplugged\\" in modern parlance).<br /><br />A good example of the \\"unplugged\\" sound of the second album would be \\"Song of the Naturalists Wife\\" with a simple banjo accompaniment.<br /><br />This box set quickly became my favorite album at the time.  However, after moving into more Jazz-fusion and Prog rock in the 1970s, I gradually stopped listening to this.<br /><br />Recently I began digitalizing my old vinyl albums.  When I recorded these albums, I realized how much I missed listening to this.  The music is so fresh and innocent.  Listening to it is like a refreshing breath of cool ocean breeze.<br /><br />However, the old vinyl was filled with skips and pops which were a large detraction.  So this was the first of the vinyl albums that I felt compelled to get a new CD of.<br /><br />Given how old this album is, it would have been nice if they had included some alternate takes, bonus tracks etc.  However, I still feel it was worth every penny just to get a pristine new digital version of this truly unique and wonderful box set.<br /><br />UPDATE:<br />I just realized that Amazon never verified this purchase for some reason.  I not only had this LP years ago, but also purchased a new CD from Amazon.  Somehow their accounting got screwed up.um would be \\"Song of the Naturalists Wife\\" with a simple banjo accompaniment.    This box set quickly became my favorite album at the time.  However, after moving into more Jazz-fusion and Prog rock in the 1970s, I gradually stopped listening to this.    Recently I began digitalizing my old vinyl albums.  When I recorded these albums, I realized how much I missed listening to this.  The music is so fresh and innocent.  Listening to it is like a refreshing breath of cool ocean breeze.      However, the old vinyl was filled with skips and pops which were a large detraction.  So this was the first of the vinyl albums that I felt compelled to get a new CD of. 0439796644|5.0|War Horse by Michael Morpurgo     Imagine  a British cavalry unit in the early days of WW I, sabers brandished, charging an entrenched foe deployed in trenches,   protected by  barbed wire and the surrounding woods,  fortified with blazing machine guns.  Of the men and horses in the British attack, only one of their valiant captains   (the other one was killed in the charge) and two of their magnificent horses broke through the German lines. The officer was taken prisoner, the horses pressed into ambulance transport service. Joey, and his sidekick Topthorn, went in that instant from being the pride of their cavalry unit to war horses serving the German army.      \\"War Horse\\" (1982) is Joey's story and it is told from the horse's point of view. The author's decision to have Joey tell the story is a literary device that dates back to \\"Black Beauty\\" (1877. Morpurgo made the decision after he witnessed a boy with such a severe stutter that he hadn't uttered a word in two years speak fluently to a horse in his care at the Morpurgo farm for poor children. He was struck by how well they understood each other.      The story begins with Joey's days on the farm in the English country side where it formed a strong attachment to Albert, the boy who treasured him and trained him before his father sold Joey to British Army at the outset of the war. A favorite of the soldiers it served with on both sides, Joey was in the thick of the fighting for months on end and emerges with the scars to prove it.     Morpurgo, Britain's pre-eminent children's book author (he has 120 to his credit) told the New York Times (see article in The Arts section in the April 12, 2011 edition) that the publication of \\"War Horse\\" in 1982 was a \\"huge nonevent\\". It pretty much remained so until 2007 when the Handspring Puppet Company of South Africa presented a dramatic version of the book at London's National Theater.  The horses in the story were created as life-sized puppets. The Times reports that \\"theplay was a huge, emotional triumph, leaving audiences wrung out and weeping.\\" From there, book sales flourished. Scholastic Press, its U.S. publisher, has already sold over 500,000 copies.  Now the play can be seen at the Lincoln Center Theater in New York and Steven Spielberg's film version will reach movie houses in December, 2011.

Blu-Ray brings the movie home like you've never see it before, and the extras that come with it are marvelous.  Highly recommended to any Bruce Lee or martial arts movie fan.

I'd partied until I blacked out and forgot what state I was in until the cops told me in jail. I'd built choppers, owner exotic cars, and averaged $1400/month in bars. I was no where near the level of these guys, but as close as i could get and still maintain an engineering career. Our addictions at some extent have held back the achievements we could have made with our combined creativity and intelligence, but we've lived more experiences in our lives than most people even imagine. After the last couple weeks, we even both temporarily died twice, and doctors had to kickstart our hearts. We're both extremists that have to abstain to survive since we never could learn to temper our self-destructive nature.\\"<br /><br />I sent a copy of my book to Nikki, letting him know how much that book inspired me and helped me through that time in my life. 014241011X|4.0|How fun is Roald Dahl?!  He is, to my mind, without a doubt one of the most imaginative human beings to ever live.  He manages to write children's books that adults also love; books that are best categorized as \\"odd\\" yet also somehow timeless and classic.  [[ASIN:014241011X The Witches]] is one that I had actually never read as a child - I picked it up at a used book sale recently and decided it was long past time I read it.  And I was not disappointed.  Dahl has a rare gift - the ability to turn an adult into a child again simply through the use of words.  He paints his world so evocatively - his descriptions of the trials and tribulations of being a more-than-usually-clever child trapped in a more-than-usually-challenging adult world make it possible for even the most grown-up grown up to remember what it is to be small and uncertain and reliant on others.  I, for one, will never look at \\"ordinary women\\" entirely the same again...

0743298039|5.0|This is the rarest of rarities - a story that had a twist that I did not see coming.  I love when that happens - especially when it occurs as a result of beautiful and evocative storytelling.  [[ASIN:0743298039 The Thirteenth Tale]] is a joy to read - or listen to (even though I am not normally a fan of audiobooks, believe me, this one is worth listening to - the clipped British accent lends the appropriate gravitas to the story and makes it an auditory as well as intellectual treat).  The interwoven stories of Vida, the famous author with an unknown past, and Margaret, the ing&eacute;nue hand-picked to reveal it, are delicately tangled together into a complex and strangely unified whole that is sure to capture your imagination.  The cast of supporting characters is impressive both in scale and scope - as are the settings for the various chapters of each woman's life.  It is a mystery wrapped in an enigma twisted around a secret - and I virtually guarantee you will not be able to put it down until you know exactly how the pieces fit together.

0385341679|3.0|I hate when a series starts out like a house afire and ends with a trickle of water.  The Fever series was, for me, a prime example of this.  It started out fabulously (I have reviews of the other books, if you are interested - just go to my review page) - it was never high literature but the series presented a fun and interesting take on the urban fantasy theme, strong characters, and generally engaging writing.  I waited and waited for [[ASIN:0385341679 Shadowfever]], the final installment - and then after I had finished it, I wondered what had happened, both to the story and the series.  I don't need every book to wind up neatly with resolution on every question and happy warm fuzziness overcoming everyone - but I do need to understand why things ended the way they did, and with this book I did not.  Mac's journey from sweet innocent Georgia girl to dark violent righteous whatever-she-is was an intriguing one, but I still feel like it is unfinished - and for the purported final book in a series, that is an unsatisfying feeling.

0786852550|4.0|To compare the Bartimaeus Trilogy to Harry Potter is like comparing apples and oranges.  They are both fantasy novels about a young boy going into manhood.  Similarities end there.  In MANY fantasy books magic is hidden from society.  In this series magic runs society.      One thing I like that others seemed to have found fault with was the characterization of Nathaniel and Bartimaeus.  Nathaniel is a product of his environment.  Yes, when you take a child from his parents and place him in the home of a stranger where they will not love him, but essentially force feed him a twisted ideal of how the world should be, you will get a character that is difficult to like.  It's the passion from the characters that makes them likeable in these stories not neseccarily their actions.      Bart is just plain sarcastic and fun.  I love the footnotes.  I love the bragging and bravado.      If you want a different more mature view of an interesting magical world pick up the trilogy.  I can't promise you won't be disappointed, but if you're a fantasy freak like me I can't see how you could be.    Now my essense aches so this is where I'll be dismissing myself.  Enjoy!

B00064WSNW|4.0|Beat and Three of a Perfect Pair aren't even in the same league.  Discipline has BOTH of those albums beat (hehe) in terms of melody and instrumental sections that actually delight listeners (in addition to the majority of the album not sounding nearly as dated as the next two King Crimson albums- with the exception of \\"The Sheltering Sky\\" perhaps).    I actually like \\"The Sheltering Sky\\".  Yes it is perhaps overdone with the amount of guitar synths (or whatever those things are- I suppose they are simply referred to these day as \\"Frippertronics\\", whatever).  It doesn't take away from the fact the song is fairly melodic and does actually create a mood.  Of course the mood that's presented here can be found in numerous 80's songs by several other bands, but who cares- I like it.  By the way, not to criticize or lessen the impact of the song or anything, but I have a hard time referring to it as jazzy.  It just feels a little too fruity to ever consider putting it in the same league as jazz, but maybe that's just me.    Now with the rest of King Crimson's 80's discography, I make constant comparisons to the Talking Heads, Duran Duran or the final period of the Police.  I can't really compare any of the stuff on Discipline to *any* of those bands.  This means Discipline is a unique album that most certainly deserves your attention.    Songs like \\"Elephant Talk\\" and \\"Thela Hun Ginjeet\\" are just so incredibly melodic with slight touches of bizarre experimentation that it works brilliantly.  I love these songs.  The idea here is to be experimental just enough to excite listeners, but not distract them... and it works.    Oh sure I could nitpick and say that the actual talking bits in \\"Elephant Talk\\" are pointless but the way the lead singer raises his voice during the \\"Talk talk talk, conversations, criticisms!\\" line is really cool.  Plus the cheesiness of the elephant-roaring sound effects using *some* kind of computer equipment (or perhaps it's a guitar- again, it's really difficult to sort out what's actually taking place) is not only quite hilarious, but *memorable*.  Perhaps \\"Thela Hun Ginjeet\\" is distractingly repetitive and doesn't deserve being over 6 minutes long, but the rhythm is splendid and downright groovy, so I don't mind.  I can definitely do without the talking bits in THIS case, though.      A song like \\"Frame By Frame\\" has a vocal melody I'm not particularly fond of, but I've definitely heard worse.  It's still better than most of the Beat album, for example.  The title song reminds me of a Rubik's Cube for some reason, hehe.  Perhaps it's the carefully layered and repetitive instrumental chops that should be annoying... but aren't (perhaps because it's just so darn *different* from anything I've ever had the pleasure -or displeasure- of hearing before).      \\"Indiscipline\\" features a *magnificent* introduction with the melodic guitar tricks making it seem like you've just fallen under a dizzy spell.  I absolutely love this song.    No, this stuff can't compare to the older version of King Crimson, but then again, not much *can*.   I still highly recommend it though.  Discipline is most certainly a step in the right direction for a band that unfortunately didn't have many more right directions after this album was released.  In fact they got worse- a LOT worse, haha.  Oh well.  Listen to Discipline anyway.
B004LSJCJM|5.0|I've always viewed Joe's workaholic approach to spitting out albums as risky and I was worried that Dust Bowl might be \\"just another album\\". How wrong was I? With Dust Bowl Joe takes his craft to an entirely new level and firmly establishes his reputation, not only as one of the greatest blues guitarists on the planet, but also one of the greatest blues/rock artists on the planet. This album takes the legacy of his other works and builds on them to form an album with so much going on its hard to cover it all on one page - the playing is understated just enough so there is space and each song breathes, the songs are finely layered and expertly executed, the production courtesy of Kevin \\"Caveman\\" Shirley is superb, and there is a deep-deep pocket in every tune (thanks no doubt to one of the best rhythm sections ever put together in the last 10 years - Carmine Rojas on bass, Rick Melick on keys and Anton Fig on drums). This is not just a showcase of Joe's prodigious guitar licks, monster tone and - yes, it is not up for debate anymore- his signature sound. This album is more than a guitar album - this album is FUNKY with an underlying groove that puts a smile on your face or a spring in your step. Moreover,  Joe's vocal performance is by far his best yet and reveals an artist that has developed, matured and is brave enough to keep moving forward. The cameos by John Hiatt, Glenn Hughes and Vince Gill are inspired - Joe is a selfless musician and he leaves his ego at the door. I could write another 1000 words on this album, but simply suggest you sit back in the dark, crank up the volume and let that Slow Train start the journey for you. Joe is really hitting his straps now.

B004LUHQ1G|5.0|There are few bands capable of putting out a 'perfect album'. Perfection is subjective to say the least, but I firmly believe in this one. From 'Burning Bridges' to 'Walk' this album doesn't miss a beat. This is perfect.    1. Bridges Burning: The Foo's first released a 30 second clip of this song about a month before the albums release and it left me begging for more. Killer, energetic opening. Great lyrics. Grohl and the crew love writing songs that they can start shows off 'with a bang' with and this is certainly a show starter. This song demonstrates why having 3 guitarists is a blessing.     2. Rope: This song took a little while to grow on me. It was released as a first single, so I was expecting something along the lines of 'The Pretender'. This song is not my favorite on the album, but I find myself loving it more and more none-the-less.    3. Dear Rosemary: Everytime I listen to this track I think to myself, \\"Why the heck do I keep passing this track up?\\". It's an incredible song with an awesome groove. I think I keep passing it because of the sheer magnitude of all the tracks that I haven't been able to focus on this one or 'Miss the Misery' enough.     4. White Limo: Dave: \\"Seriously guys! We only have this Limo for another hour! Taylor! Grab your camcorder! It's song time!\\"... And this is the story of how the most intense song on the album was made. There is no way to stop your head from banging. DON'T RESIST.    5. Arlandria: This in my mind is the second single. It's the song I've listened to the most, it's catchy and well written. With lyrics like \\"Use me up! Spit me out! Let me be your hand me down!\\"... This song eminates a fist-pumping beauty.    6. These Days: Powerful song. The chorus reminds me of something that belongs on 'In Your Honor'. This song demonstrates Dave's mastery of lyrics.    7. Back & Forth: Classic 90's FOO. This song speaks for itself.    8. A Matter of Time: The Pre-chorus to this song threw me off a bit at first. The verse sounds like it's about to lead into something totally different, but changes pace a bit. However, it's grown on me and I can't stop listening to this song at the moment. Lovin' it.    9. Miss the Misery: I've read a few of reviews where people claim this is there least favorite song on the album. I personally think people are just to pre-occupied with other songs to concentrate on this one. In all honesty, if this song were on 'Echoes, Silence, Patience and Grace', I think it would have been the second or third single. This album is that good.    10. I Should Have Known: This song is Hauntingly beautiful. I can still feel it echoing throughout my bones.    11. Walk: Wow. What can I say about this song... 2:07-3:10. This is the most powerful, emotional part of the entire album.    Sorry for only putting 5 stars. But sadly, there isn't a higher option available... I encourage any fan of Rock music to purchase this album and enjoy.

Some ideas from the book: if you don't want to sell your business in the future, you have no business starting a company. In the history of mankind, nobody has ever made a rational buying decision - they couldn't if they wanted to because NOBODY knows how. It's all rote, it's all formula, it's all a system from which you must not deviate.     One chapter gives an example: the author will never go back to that barber again. The three times he went the haircut was very good. The problem is the barber used scissors-only once and a combination of a trimmer and scissors another time. One time they offered him coffee and the next time they offered him wine. That just drove him nuts. Consistency is not more important than quality. For this writer consistency is the definition of quality. McDonalds is the best hamburger in the world because it is the same each time you order it. There is a whole chapter on how much he adores McDonalds.     Finally, what I really did not like was the black-and-white tone. This is the ONLY way to do it. Do it any other way and you will lose all your money, your business will fail and everybody will know you are a loser. 0451167716|5.0|The Godfather, by Mario Puzo, is a book about the mafia in New York. It takes place in the 1940s all the way through the 1950s. It gives a backstory of Vito Corleone, the Don, and his early life in America. During this, you will learn how the infamous Don Corleone was introduced to a life of crime. This is an amazing classic that will hold the reader from start to finish. Also, you will see a startling change in one character that will shock you from the moment you read about it.   The Godfather will never fail to surprise you through its pages. The story begins at the wedding of Connie Corleone, the Don's daughter. After a request from his godson, Don Corleone takes matters into his own hands when it comes to a movie producer. Before an attempt on his father's life, Michael Corleone always stayed away from his father's way of life. No one reading would ever suspect what Michael would turn out to be. When Sollozo, a drug dealer, arranges to meet with Michael, Michael Corleone shoots him. This proved to be the turning point in Michael's life when he officially entered the mafia world. He later becomes the Don of the Corleone family. Not only that, but while in hiding, his brother, Sonny, was killed.      This is a realistic fiction book because it shows the life and actions of the mafia. However, the characters in this story are not based on real people. Michael went from a law-respecting citizen to a criminal, changing in almost every way. The readers learn that even though Vito Corleone is the leader of a mafia family, he is an intelligent man who is known for being respected by both his friends and enemies. The Corleone Family is a mixture of young and old Italians. One of the oldest, Vito Corleone, was the original Don and his youngest son, Michael, is the current one. This book is intended for anyone who enjoys suspense, mystery, and surprises.

0316069353|5.0|THE FIFTH WITNESS by Michael Connelly is properly put in the Lincoln Lawyer concordance --- Harry Bosch makes an appearance, but don't blink or you'll miss it --- probably scheduled to coincide with the release of the film version of the introductory book. It is a \\"courtroom\\" or \\"legal\\" thriller by any definition, going from the client's arrest to trial preparation, trial and denouement. If one wants an unvarnished look into the professional life of a criminal trial attorney, this is it.    It has been said elsewhere --- tongue in cheek, of course --- that the practice of law would be a great profession if not for the clients. While the majority of clients encountered in virtually every area of law are reasonable, one does --- as with any job --- deal with people who are difficult; indeed, Mickey Haller has his hands more than full with Lisa Trammel. Haller has recently changed direction and focus in his practice due to some simple economics. There are fewer criminal defendants with the ability to pay the fees he needs to earn a living; accordingly, he is involved with defending homeowners in foreclosure actions.    Things take a bit of a turn when Trammel, one of his new foreclosure clients, is accused of murder and requests --- nay, demands! --- that Haller defend her. Trammel is well known as an activist on the issue of homeowner foreclosures and illegal bank practices. The murder victim, a bank vice-president named Mitchell Bondurant, had attracted Trammel's ire to the extent that a restraining order had been issued against her, compelling her to stay away from Bondurant and his place of employment. Trammel loudly and repeatedly proclaims her innocence, but there is eyewitness and forensic evidence against her. Haller's efforts to defend her are complicated by her personality --- she knows just enough to get herself in trouble and to pour sand into Haller's defense tank --- and her relationship with a shady movie agent.    But when Haller is warned away from thecase by a couple of thugs who administer a rather vicious beatdown, it simply makes him even more tenacious in his defense of the client. He needs every bit of his skills and talents, as well as those of his somewhat edgy support staff, to combat the ferocity of the district attorney prosecuting the case, a fireball against whom Haller has batted zero to date. As the proceedings seesaw back and forth, Haller deals with both professional and personal challenges that take him to the brink and beyond. Even after the trial has concluded, Haller is on the giving and receiving ends of a number of surprises, some of which undoubtedly will have ramifications in future installments of the series.    There are two extremely impressive elements in THE FIFTH WITNESS. The first is Connelly's effort to get the essence of criminal client representation correct, down to the last nuance. I have already mentioned the second --- the climactic series of surprises at the end of the book, which consist of a minor revelation and two major ones. Those who do not enjoy extended courtroom scenarios may find the going a little slow by the final third of the story (although one would expect a book about a lawyer to have a good deal of that) but should hang in all the way to the end. Your patience will be rewarded, not only by the conclusion, but also by the sample of THE DROP, the new Harry Bosch novel to be published in November.        --- Reviewed by Joe Hartlaub
B000FCKGPC|4.0|I started with [[ASIN:B004H99QQ4 A Game of Thrones (A Song of Ice and Fire #1) by George R. R. Martin]] intending to finish that book before the HBO series started.  I quickly became caught up in the series and the world of Westeros living it with each page.  Each book I finished left me exhausted with not just the length, but the twist and turns, schemes and plots and I hesitated to begin the next knowing the journey that lay ahead.  Yet, each time I dove into the next book and not only finished \\"Game\\", but all of the series published to date.    I read the reviews of [[ASIN:0553582038 A Feast for Crows (A Song of Ice and Fire, Book 4)]] and dreaded reading this book because of them, considered skipping it.  Instead, I decided to skim the book in preparation of the publication of [[ASIN:0553801473 A Dance with Dragons (Song of Ice and Fire)]].  I did not skim as intended.  I plowed through this one as I did the previous books.    Many have critizied the book for lacking focus on many of our favorite characters, so much so I expected to know no one.  Thank goodness this was not so.  Many of the characters are there and having read the previous books, most readers can realize that those who do not appear have something important going on elsewhere that we will find out about later.  The title of the first, \\"Game of Thrones\\" is a true description of this series.  The first three novels introduced us to the world, drew us in, let us know the characters, unveiled schemes and plots then hit us with the final pages just as a good clifthanger will, because; just as with life, there are no final resolutions.  \\"Feast\\" carries on that tradition taking us in directions we never expected yet, it may be giving us a glimpse of the \\"grand plan\\" ... or does it?.  I have to say, Martin has crafted this series as well as great mystery writers craft their best \\"who-dun-its\\".  What happens in \\"Feast\\" is as important to the overall story as the previous three books and having read it, I'm not sure how the series could have continued if \\"Feast\\" had not been written.    I'm looking forward to \\"Dance\\" and I can't wait for the HBO series to start.

0930073207|5.0|I read Economics in One Lesson by Henry Hazlitt more than a year ago with my then 10-yr. old son. The knowledge in it is so profound that I've put off writing this review for fear that I could never do it justice, and I'm sure I haven't. But there's no time to wait - you need to read this book now.<br /><br />Having read a number of books about economics and banking, history and politics, I believe that Economics In One Lesson stands out as the most important book on the subject area.<br /><br />It is setup as a series of 23 different examples describing everyday occurrences to illustrate fundamental economic principles. How a broken window impacts the overall wealth of the community is among the most famous of these examples. Others address the value of public works projects, the importance of exports, the impact of taxation on production, the relationship of employment to the minimum wage and the inflationary result of printing money.<br /><br />Though written more than 50 years ago, the examples remain all too relevant today, unfortunately. In fact, for nearly every example, I was able to clip an article from the newspaper or print one from the Web documenting how the same issues are sadly alive today. \\"Price Controls Hamper Rise of Generics\\", Wall Street Journal, for example, revealed how the government of the Philippines set price controls on branded drugs to lower their cost only to find the artificially reduced profits caused retailers to cancel planned store openings and stop hiring. Hospitals raised other prices to recoup the loss of revenue from drugs and the once-growing generic drug manufacturing industry stalled since the spread between its prices and the now-lower branded drugs has been cut. Now there are more people unemployed and less medicine available. If only government officials in the Philippines had read this book before causing so much needless and predictable suffering.<br /><br />In \\"The New Cannery Row\\", for a second example, Wall Street Journal editors reveal what happened to the tuna industry in American Samoa when our Congress required the U.S. territory to raise its minimum wage from $3.26 an hour to $7.25 an hour by 2015. Well, what do you think happened? Chicken of the Sea closed its plant. StarKist cut more than half its workforce. Thousands were put out of work. The minimum wage hike pushed unemployment from 10% to 30%. Seems workers in Thailand are willing to clean fish for $.75 an hour. Since our Congress failed to grasp this, we get to send $18 million of our taxes to Samoa as compensation. Oops.<br /><br />Had our Congressmen read Hazlitt's analysis of each occurrence and his predictions for the outcomes of each occurrence under different economic policies they would've understood how raising and lowering the minimum wage affects employment. In fact, the answers to nearly every economic challenge that seems to confound everyone from TV talking heads to Federal Reserve members and the President's team of economic advisors are in this book, quickly and simply laid out for anyone to understand - regardless of a passing grade in Economics 101.<br /><br />In fact, the policy answers are so obvious that my 10-yr. old, upon noticing the \\"50th Anniversary Edition\\" sticker on the cover, was baffled that the world could be in such economic chaos when the answers have been right here for 50 years. He'd thought we were reading a new book -it was unfathomable that most of our political leaders have ignored the obvious for so long while continually throwing money at policies that are proven to fail everywhere they've been implemented.<br /><br />After reading Economics In One Lesson, it's easy to see through all of the fear and hysteria driving today's pseudo-journalists on the news.  I highly recommend Economics In One Lesson. This book needs to be at the top of your reading list.ed to the tuna industry in American Samoa when our Congress required the U.S. territory to raise its minimum wage from $3.26 an hour to $7.25 an hour by 2015. Well, what do you think happened? Chicken of the Sea closed its plant. StarKist cut more than half its workforce. Thousands were put out of work. The minimum wage hike pushed unemployment from 10% to 30%. Seems workers in Thailand are willing to clean fish for $.75 an hour. Since our Congress failed to grasp this, we get to send $18 million of our taxes to Samoa as compensation. Oops.    Had our Congressmen read Hazlitt's analysis of each occurrence and his predictions for the outcomes of each occurrence under different economic policies they would've understood how raising and lowering the minimum wage affects employment. In fact, the answers to nearly every economic challenge that seems to confound everyone from TV talking heads to Federal Reserve members and the President's team of economic advisors are in this book, quickly and simply laid out for anyone to understand - regardless of a passing grade in Economics 101.    In fact, the policy answers are so obvious that my 10-yr. old, upon noticing the \\"50th Anniversary Edition\\" sticker on the cover, was baffled that the world could be in such economic chaos when the answers have been right here for 50 years. He'd thought we were reading a new book -it was unfathomable that most of our political leaders have ignored the obvious for so long while continually throwing money at policies that are proven to fail everywhere they've been implemented.    After reading Economics In One Lesson, it's easy to see through all of the fear and hysteria driving today's pseudo-journalists on the news.  I highly recommend Economics In One Lesson. This book needs to be at the top of your reading list.

B003UESJH4|5.0|The King's Speech is neither the most complex nor the most original film of the year, but this beautiful film stands out in that it requires the audience to have an attention span. The movie follows Prince Albert (Colin Firth), nicknamed Bertie, in Pre-World War II England as he attempts to overcome, or at least cope with, his stammer. His wife Her Royal Highness Elizabeth (Helena Bonham Carter) recruits Australian speech therapist Lionel Logue (Geoffrey Rush) and so begins Bertie's unconventional path to Kinghood and self-acceptance.    Visuals are sometimes self-conscious and even cartoonish, but coloring is used to excellent effect. Lionel encourages Bertie to break away from social constraints, and his space is appropriately off-kilter, while the foreboding, increasingly dark shots of Bertie's surroundings have the effect of a vice. A stunning Colin Firth successfully conveys Bertie's vulnerability, which is made all the more harrowing because of his lack of self-pity. Geoffrey Rush complements Firth's performance and brings his delightful dialog to life as the alternately cheeky and tender Lionel.    Bertie's history of pain and stress is expressed in his body. The mechanical advice of physicians of the day falls flat, as does the advice to merely \\"relax.\\" Lionel offers a deeper connection, one which will likely inspire numerous viewers who have struggled with feelings of inadequacy and isolation. The film highlights the strict social structure as a source of damaging pressure. Bertie's life has almost no relationship to his struggling subjects, and yet the descriptions of his upbringing are horrifying. Lionel has a content family but, as an Australian, faces frequent prejudice. In spite of its heaviness, the film is quite funny as well. Bertie's dry sense of humor and Lionel's insouciance light up many a scene and amplify the more serious moments.    The two most interesting minor characters are Bertie's father King George V (Michael Gambon) and brother David(Guy Pearce), later King Edward VII, both of whom play a major role in Bertie's pathology. Gambon's George is a man with little patience for weakness, and Pearce's David is a silly, unfortunate product of his family.    Helena Bonham Carter does well with a less fleshed-out part. Lionel's wife (played by Jennifer Ehle) may be too perfect, but Lionel's and Bertie's families are portrayed with a light, lovely touch. Winston Churchill (Timothy Spall) is a purely positive and somewhat simplistic figure, and Archbishop Cosmo Lang (Derek Jacobi) is almost pure oiliness. Still, most characters are believable and very much of their time. Even the most progressive characters do not seem to be artificially implanted with modern ideas.    The horrors of World War I quietly hang over the characters, making the impending World War II all the more forboding. This might have been a more powerful film had it focused more on the threat ahead. Whatever the case, the painfully beautiful climax evokes a sense of both tragedy and victory and manages to be simultaneously heartrending and uplifting.    The King's Speech is less a political study than a poignant depiction of the power in treating another like a human being, even a king.
